before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"3s0uq","text":"Appropriate computational resources must be available to run the tools and web-servers mentioned in the protocol. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
description: {"blocks":[{"key":"9cvqg","text":"Comprehending the toxicity and other adverse effects of any given set of potential natural repellent molecules against various proteins in humans is essential to determine their safety prior to their use in formulations. An in-silico computational protocol provided in this article can be used to determine the toxicity of any given molecule against the entire human proteome and thus build a safety profile for the same. Preliminary toxicity predictions for oral, dermal and inhalation routes were made for the natural small molecules using computational tools such as Protox-II, SwissADME and T.E.S.T. The screening of the whole proteome to determine the off-targets was then conducted for a given set of natural small molecules with similar mode of action. Tools such as LigTMap, PharmMapper, Swiss Target Predictions and SuperPRED were used for off-target determination. Selection criteria were employed to shortlist the most interacting and probable off-targets to the ligands. These shortlisted protein targets were then manually docked using Schrodinger and the best and poor docked complexes were simulated at 100ns in the Desmond suite of Schrodinger to assess the stability of binding. The final safety profile was then designed after collating all the results obtained from the above-mentioned analyses, considering all parameters. The recommended set of natural small molecules can be visualized for better understandability using a bar chart from the safety profile created for the given set of molecules. This protocol can thus be employed for testing the toxicity and safety of any ligand computationally, so these predictions maybe used prior to any in-vitro studies, to understand the preliminary safety challenges. ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":224,"length":10},{"style":"italic","offset":1666,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c9gsv","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cq7q8","text":"Keywords: Human safety evaluation, proteome, natural small molecules, repellents, off-targets and toxicity, molecular docking and simulations","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":141}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

UniProt has the updated total number of proteins in the human proteome. This protocol has the numbers that were, at the time the total number of proteins that were available. steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"cdpnt","text":"The toxicity predictions for the given set of potential molecules with mosquito repellent activities were first tested via several tools. The detailed description for each is provided below.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"c0jqh","text":"Protox-II","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"qmv","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4i7sk","text":"This tool predicts the primary toxicity properties of all natural small molecules to help generate a safety profile via oral routes. It also provides the acute toxicity values. The analysis of toxicity of each small molecule revealed its probable levels of target organ toxicity towards humans, if and when these were consumed accidentally. Protox-II (https://tox-new.charite.de/protox_II/)employs machine learning (ML) models to predict endpoints of toxicities such as acute toxicity, hepato-toxicity, cyto-toxicity, mutagenicity, immunotoxicity, carcinogenicity and other adverse outcomes via Tox-21 pathways. ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":352,"length":37}],"data":{}},{"key":"9smi7","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5h12u","text":"Protox-II also provides information regarding the probability of organs/targets in the human body that the repellent molecules are active or inactive to, providing an idea on the oral toxicity predictions. ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fgi40","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7toio","text":"Analysis of Protox II results","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":29},{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":29}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fnufc","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"pi6v","text":"The Protox-II outcomes revealed specific threshold values to interpret the toxicity predictions. The toxic doses are provided as LD50 values in mg/kg body weight. LD50 values are the lethal dose at which 50% of the test animals die upon exposure to the compound. Thus, higher the LD50 value, lower the toxicity. ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b95ai","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"vr7r","text":"The toxicity classes are also provided in Protox-II as an outcome and are described as follows according to the GHS Classification criteria (https://www.era-environmental.com/blog/ghs-hazard-classification).","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":141,"length":64}],"data":{}},{"key":"pi7h","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1ei4i","text":"Class I: fatal (LD50 ≤ 5)","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"47nuu","text":"Class II: fatal (5 \u003c LD50 ≤ 50)","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f9uud","text":"Class III: average toxicity (50 \u003c LD50 ≤ 300)","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bvet6","text":"Class IV: non-toxic, safe to use (300 \u003c LD50 ≤ 2000)","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8sbqv","text":"Class V: non-toxic (2000 \u003c LD50 ≤ 5000)","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eead9","text":"Class VI: non-toxic (LD50 \u003e 5000)","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3o5r2","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b5ev1","text":"Acute toxicity refers to the adverse effects following an oral or dermal administration of a substance. Thus, to estimate and predict acute toxicity, Protox-II and SwissADME (explained in the next section) were used.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bsfr9","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9n54h","text":"Table {"blocks":[{"key":"b5gan","text":"SwissADME ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9g05q","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"51hbe","text":"It is important to understand dermal toxicity predictions prior to using a given set of naturals in repellent formulations. This was understood using SwissADME (http://www.swissadme.ch/) that predicts the skin permeation along with other ADME and pharmacokinetic parameters. ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":161,"length":24}],"data":{}},{"key":"3necp","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5q51i","text":"SwissADME computes the ADME properties (Absorption, distribution, metabolism, excretion) of the naturals, and other pharmacokinetic attributes. It is essential to understand the various pharmacokinetic properties of potential natural repellent molecules since when used in formulations, they may find their way to human skin/body through multiple routes of exposures such as dermal, oral or aspiration. Thus, an idea on its pharmacokinetic safety is crucial. Thus, all the naturals that were run on Protox II were also subjected to SwissADME studies. ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5fvf5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8u3j3","text":"The properties studied included: ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f96f","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8fs1b","text":"1. Human gastrointestinal absorption (HIA): estimation of the permeability into the human GI system.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cuj7i","text":"2. Interaction with cytochrome molecules (CYP450): for comprehending adverse effects of naturals.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5p4ua","text":"3. Blood-brain barrier (BBB) permeation: This barrier protects the central nervous system from exposure to any molecules that have a toxic effect. Thus, it is pivotal to understand if a compound is a BBB permeant.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"da31o","text":"4. Skin permeation (Kp): Prediction of Kp values determine the transport of the molecule through the mammalian epidermis. More negative the log Kp value is, lesser the skin permeation.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fbrer","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"etc9","text":"The route of exposure: dermal","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"1CE5BD5E10BB11EE9A3E0A58A9FEAC02","url":"http://www.swissadme.ch"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6jlvi","text":"T.E.S.T Tool","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2lo1a","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ffsv8","text":"T.E.S.T (https://www.epa.gov/chemical-research/toxicity-estimation-software-tool-test)predicts the general small molecule properties that can help in comprehension of the natural small molecules. But, aside that, this tool predicts two types of toxicities: ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":9,"length":76}],"data":{}},{"key":"9sni0","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6epah","text":"1. Developmental toxicity (DevTox): estimates if the molecule is involved in causing any developmental toxicity to humans.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fm1rt","text":"The route of exposure studied in this tool: Oral and inhalation","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fg742","text":"2. AMES mutagenicity: this tool detects if a specific molecule can cause mutations in the DNA of the test organism, in this case, humans. {"blocks":[{"key":"dq1ed","text":"Screening of the human proteome","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":31}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"68teo","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5ernp","text":"The human proteome consists of approximately 81,837 proteins (Proteome ID UP000005640). It is thus essential to screen the entire proteome to identify if the potential insecticide components have any effect on the human proteins. For this purpose, a protocol was developed to screen the entire proteome and develop a safety profile for a given set of naturals to comprehend their toxicity/adverse effects on humans prior to being taken forth for repellent formulations. ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":61,"length":27}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":74,"length":11}],"data":{}},{"key":"2p6b6","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"clnhe","text":"The UniProt organism ID used for this study was 9606. The screening of the entire proteome was carried out by identification and prediction of off-targets for the given set of potential repellent natural small molecules. Off-target identification was performed using several bioinformatic tools and databases. These databases are known to have most of the identified proteins in the human proteome, thereby, covering the maximum stretch of the proteome for off-target-search and analysis.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2l4ml","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"36e0h","text":"Thus, out of ~81K proteins, off-target search revealed ~7995 proteins, after elimination of all repetitive proteins. The reason for shortlisting about ~7995 is because off-target search is specific for every ligand. The search results are provided for only those molecules that have a possibility of binding to the molecule in question. A specific selection criterion was then employed to further narrow down our off-targets that had to be taken forward for manual docking studies. The selection criteria is provided in the following sections. All repetitive targets and duplicates were eliminated again to further narrow down the proteins. The final shortlisted and identified off-targets of the repellent molecules were then docked against the given set of molecules, followed by analysis of docked complexes and molecular dynamic studies for the best docked and worst docked complexes. ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"du5rh","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"EE644D2010BE11EE9A3E0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.uniprot.org/proteomes/UP000005640"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1ra1g","text":"Prediction of off-targets of small molecules in human","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":53}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"frhdt","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4rgk6","text":"The binding of the ligands to protein targets other than those for which the ligands were originally meant to bind are called off-targets. In this study, the authors predicted the off-targets in the entire human proteome for a given set of naturals to determine the effect of these natural small molecules on targets other than their own. Prediction of off-targets was carried out using various tools, including, LigTMap (https://cbbio.online/LigTMap/),PharmMapper (http://www.lilab-ecust.cn/pharmmapper/), SwissTargetPrediction (http://www.swisstargetprediction.ch/) and SuperPRED (https://prediction.charite.de/). These tools search the entire databases and finds all possible off-targets for each natural molecule in Homo sapiens. ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":720,"length":14}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":422,"length":29},{"key":1,"offset":466,"length":38},{"key":2,"offset":530,"length":36},{"key":3,"offset":583,"length":30}],"data":{}},{"key":"2ujr4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"12FE05EF10BF11EE9A3E0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://cbbio.online/LigTMap"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"12FE063A10BF11EE9A3E0A58A9FEAC02","url":"http://www.lilab-ecust.cn/pharmmapper"}},"2":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"12FE067610BF11EE9A3E0A58A9FEAC02","url":"http://www.swisstargetprediction.ch"}},"3":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"12FE06AE10BF11EE9A3E0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://prediction.charite.de"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8q1j8","text":"LigTMap","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8kbmn","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"u26m","text":"This tool identifies off-targets from various classes of human protein targets by combining the ligand similarity searches with docking and binding similarity score analyses to predict the proteins. Every protein belongs to specific classes, based on which the targets were identified. Outcomes include PDB (Protein Databank) IDs of the targets, binding similarity scores, predicted affinity and probable binding energies of the given set of naturals to the human proteins. ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2jnv5","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"vk0i","text":"PharmMapper","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4m63n","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7k14f","text":"This tool works on the principle of pharmacophore mapping and is highly efficient due to its high-throughput approach. PharmMapper functions as a tool for recognizing off-targets and other new compounds with information on its biological activity. Thus, for further examination, all targets with Z-score ≥ 1 were screened. ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"958ub","text":"SwissTarget ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"55snd","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3vmf2","text":"This tool estimates the most probable targets of the selected bioactives in a given organism, including humans. Probability values are obtained as outcomes that indicate the binding probability of the naturals to the predicted protein targets. ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

The results are provided as probability scores and model accuracies of the ML model used for prediction. {"blocks":[{"key":"5f5c9","text":"Selection criteria for off-target predictions","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":45}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f4o8v","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"efbul","text":"Every tool used for the prediction of off-targets in humans provide several protein targets with the possibility of binding via docking scores. However, since all the targets cannot be selected for manual docking purposes, the selection criteria were set to narrow down the overall number of protein targets that maybe studied further and, on whose functions/pathways the natural small molecules may have an effect. ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f0t72","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a6f9","text":"Therefore, using the selection criteria provided below, and removal of all duplicates identified from each tool, 614 proteins were shortlisted to test effect of natural small molecules on them via manual molecular docking. ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9dlgi","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"23l3f","text":"Table 3: The selection criteria for each tool used for off-target predictions and shortlisting the protein targets, along with their significance","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":145}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"agecr","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8h68v","text":" Tools used Overall results Selected targets Selection Criteria Significance LigTMap 150 10 LigTMap score >= 0.5 Protein targets are ranked based on LigTMap score. {"blocks":[{"key":"7jeu3","text":"Molecular docking","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"crrt0","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"51ctq","text":"Docking studies of a given set of ligands against shortlisted human protein targets were carried out using Schrodinger. All 614 proteins were prepared individually using the protein preparation wizard in Schrodinger. All the given natural small molecules along with positive and negative controls were prepared via ligprep wizard. All the conformers that were generated during ligand preparation were considered for docking. For this, cross docking technique was employed, where multiple protein and multiple ligands docking was carried out for all shortlisted human protein targets (obtained from screening of the human proteome) against the given set of ligands. ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a965n","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dm5n","text":"Docking was carried out by first importing the ligands to Schrodinger Maestro. The maximum ligand size was set to 500 atoms. OPLS forcefield was applied. Epik (Schrödinger Release 2022-3: Epik, Schrödinger, LLC, New York, NY, 2021.) was used to generate all possible ligand conformations at a neutral pH of 7.0 ± 2. Once the conformers were generated, all selected proteins were prepared using the protein preparation wizard in Schrodinger. All 614 proteins were pre-processed, by optimization of the H-bond and structure minimization. The water molecules were all deleted and the prepared proteins were employed for docking using XGlide in Schrodinger. ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"fr0sr","text":"Cross-docking","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fvm5g","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9u7u8","text":"The proteins were all defined in the receptor section and the prepared ligands in the ligand section in Schrodinger. The grid box was generated and all active sites were detected using the site-map for the protein. Setting the grid box so as to cover the entire protein indicates that the whole protein will be searched for the best binding pockets when docking is performed. Cross-docking between 614 proteins and the given set of ligands was performed using high-throughput virtual screening (HTVS) and the binding energies were obtained. A thorough analysis of the best docked complexes revealed an interaction profile that aided in performing a comprehensive study on the best and poorly bound complexes that could be taken forward for simulation studies.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2sm09","text":"Analysis of cross-docking","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":25}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"946hm","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5v093","text":"Cross-docking results were analyzed using 2-dimnesional interaction software called LigPlot+ to determine the amino acid interactions, including hydrogen bonding, hydrophobic bonding, etc. against the human protein targets. The docked complexes whose stabilities were required to be checked were simulated at 100ns in Desmond Schrodinger. The interactions of the given set of ligands with the human proteins were analyzed to determine their effects.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8vi8f","text":"Molecular dynamic simulations at 100ns ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":39}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5224t","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5scdc","text":"To further establish the relationship between the protein and the natural molecule, molecular dynamic simulations at 100ns were performed to demonstrate and understand the binding stabilities of the natural small molecules to human proteins. Thus, the best docked and the poorly docked complexes were simulated at 100ns at 1000 frame trajectory. The Maestro workspace in Desmond, Schrodinger (Schrödinger Release 2022-3: Desmond Molecular Dynamics System, D. E. Shaw Research, New York, NY, 2021. Maestro-Desmond Interoperability Tools, Schrödinger, New York, NY, 2021.), was used for simulations due to its high scalability, reliability, precision, accuracy and rapidity. Prior to molecular dynamic simulations, the pre-processing of the proteins was carried out by assessing the structural errors and refining the same. Optimization was then performed for the interacting complexes via steepest descent algorithms for 500 times, followed by removal of water molecules. The simulation environment was built using the system builder in Maestro, by setting the solvent model to TIP3P, and defining the boundary boxes via an orthorhombic box that restricts and compresses the interacting complexes to 5 Å at the x, y and z axes. This system was built to constrain the simulation at 100ns within the boundary box. Addition of sodium and chloride ions neutralized the entire system. ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eggi9","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9a7lb","text":"Neutral pH of 7.0 was maintained for the system. 100ns simulations were then carried out with the trajectory recording set to 0.1ns and normal temperature and pressure (NPT) was selected as the ensemble thermodynamic parameters. ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8j4qe","text":"Development of final safety profile","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":35}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"mkv3","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5kt9n","text":"The final safety profile was then developed based on all the parameters considered and the results obtained. The natural small molecules that have low levels of toxicity or are predicted to be relatively safer from these tools and tests, are recommended for further use in wet lab, while those that affect the human protein pathways are studied further to analyse their effects. Additionally, given a large number of natural small molecules, once the entire profile is built, they may be categorized into different set of safe natural small molecules to provide appropriate recommendations for wet lab studies. ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9jrl","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ejmrd","text":"In the present protocol, after interpreting and understanding various parameters such as toxicity classes, carcinogenicity, mutagenicity, hepato-toxicity, immunotoxicity, cytotoxicity, various Tox 21 nuclear receptor signaling pathways, Tox-21 stress response pathways, Ames mutagenicity, developmental toxicity, pharmacokinetic properties such as GI absorption, blood brain barrier permeation, skin permeability, and molecular docking abilities and simulations in dynamic environments, the safety profile was built. Those that qualified the maximum number of parameters were categorized as the best set of safe natural small molecules, that could be recommended to be taken forward for further studies in the laboratory. In addition to this, the kind of toxicities were also taken into consideration for designing a safety profile, and not just the number, since the toxicity kind plays a crucial role in the altering the human protein pathways. The final profile built can be analyzed using graphical representations such as bar charts for better visualizations. ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ebp2q","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"74iai","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"9u9a4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8o7do","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"fhr1t","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"cdg43","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8iu7k","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aijqn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"result","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"fmtec","text":"The figures below show two ways of expressing the expected outcomes of the safety profile.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"4C1E3A00119611EEA220DB2820A72FAC","height":165,"id":383807,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"5ba1t\",\"text\":\"Figure 3: Expected safety profile built for a given set of natural small molecules after considering all parameters. {"blocks":[{"key":"834oo","text":"This protocol has been tried and tested against a given set of natural small molecules to assess their probable safety and develop a profile for the same. The methodology involves moving from predicting the oral, aspiration and dermal toxicity values via in-silico tools to identifying all possible off-targets in humans for the potential repellent molecules, by screening through the whole human proteome and shortlisting the targets based on a set of selection criteria mentioned in the protocol. Once the final number of possible interacting proteins that the molecules bind to are finalized, their interactions can be studied statically and dynamically via molecular docking and 100ns simulations. The aim here is to have those molecules that do not interact and affect the human protein pathways since they will be typically used in repellent/insecticide formulations. However, for better clarity, all best and poorly bound complexes can be simulated. Considering all parameters, an evaluation of the safety parameters profile maybe designed and a set of best recommendations maybe provided. This study also has future perspectives in terms of performing free energy of binding studies to obtain further insights into the complex stabilities and to use additional tools to further confirm these predictions. This protocol can be used for building an in-silico safety profile for not only natural repellent molecules, but also for any molecule whose potential safety against human proteome has to be tested.
